author: bridge-bot
content:
<GuthL> This is a statement and not a set of performance requirements. 
It is not obvious to me that CPU time is cheaper than data transmission. I might be wrong but I would love to see proof for it.
Another notable problem that I see with Verkle Trees is that they are going to break every usage of the state today (Bridges, Voting using StorageProof, and probably other things that I have top of mind) (re @dankrad: The main problem is that Merkle tree witnesses are too large and verkle trees solve this problem)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<dankrad> The compatibility issues you point out could only be solved by keeping the current hexary structure, which is even 4x worse than a binary Merkle tree in terms of witness sizes. 
I think the statement "CPU time is cheaper than data transmission" makes no sense as they have different units.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<GuthL> It does have a meaning in the context of Eth1 where gas is de facto a measure of time. (re @dankrad: The compatibility issues you point out could only be solved by keeping the current hexary structure, which is even 4x worse than a binary Merkle tree in terms of witness sizes. 
I think the statement "CPU time is cheaper than data transmission" makes no sense as they have different units.)

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> fair enough, have you estimated what the gas cost of hexary Merkle witnesses would be?

author: bridge-bot
content: <GuthL> That's my question to you. I have never seen the numbers discussed properly. If they have been, I would love to read about them. (re @dankrad: fair enough, have you estimated what the gas cost of hexary Merkle witnesses would be?)

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> you can very easily do the math on the back of an envelope

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> assume 1b state elements in the future. that means a hexary tree depth of ~9 for a witness size of 9*15*32=4320 bytes. So at the standard per byte gas rate (16/byte) that would be 16*4350 = 69120 gas per state access. At the reduced gas cost suggested for witnesses per byte that's still 17280.

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> Marginal cost of verifying 1 verkle witness is expected to be 30 us or so. at 20 million gas/s target, the CPU cost of this would be 600 gas

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> seems like a fairly good tradeoff to me?
